Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN: Collaborative: Documenting the Occurrence through Space & Time of Aquatic Non-indigenous Fish, Mollusks, Algae, & Plants Threatening North America's Great
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the greatest threats to the health of North America's Great Lakes is invasion by exotic species, several of which already have had catastrophic impacts on property values, the fisheries, shipping, and tourism industries, and continue to threaten the survival of native species and wetland ecosystems. Additional species have been placed on watchlists because of their potential to become aquatic invasives. This project will create a network of herbaria and zoology museums from among the Great Lakes states of MN, WI, IL, IN, MI, OH, and NY to better document the occurrence of these species in space and time by imaging and providing online access to the information on the specimens of the critical organisms. Several initiatives are already in place to alert citizens to the dangers of spreading aquatic invasives among our nation's waterways, but this project will develop complementary scientific and educational tools for scientists, students, wildlife officers, teachers, and the public who have had little access to images or data derived directly from preserved specimens collected over the past three centuries.

This bi-national Thematic Collections Network of >25 institutions from eight states and Canada will digitize 1.73 million historical specimens representing 2,550 species of exotic fish, clams, snails, mussels, algae, plants, and their look-alikes documented to occur in the Great Lakes Basin. It is one of the first efforts to digitize liquid preserved specimens and to integrate cross-kingdom taxa and these methods could become national standards for cross taxon digitization. Students will be provided with hands-on experience in modern methods of specimen curation and this cross-taxon network will provide greater flexibility to existing web platforms for integration of data. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this four-year project, The Morton Arboretum (1) collaborated in digitizing 1,031,000 museum specimens of aquatic invasive species from North American Museums and (2) led the development of outreach and educational materials on aquatic invasive species. Digitized specimens—in which photos of the specimens are coupled with parsed data about where, when, and by whom the specimens were collected—are a cornerstone of our understanding of how biodiversity has changed over time, and this project provides data that allow us to investigate how widely and how rapidly invasive species may be impacting wetlands of the Great Lakes region.

The Arboretum’s primary contributions included:

  • Development of curriculum materials for 8th to 12th grade students. The Morton Arboretum and the N.W. Harris Learning Collection at the Field Museum (http://harris.fieldmuseum.org/) collaborated to create six Experience Boxes for teaching specimen-based approaches to understanding invasive species to 8-12th graders. All curricular materials have been reviewed and aligned with Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). The boxes have just been launched at the outset of the 2018/2019 school year. One of these boxes is being circulated through The Morton Arboretum’s education program, targeting schools in the western suburbs. The remaining boxes will reach predominantly Chicago Public Schools through the Field Museum’s Harris Learning Collection.
  • Publication of novel identification guides. The Arboretum published a 30-page online identification guide to aquatic invasive plants, Aquatic Invasive Plants and Their Look-Alikes: A specimen-based guide to identi­fication in the Great Lakes Region (2018; A. Miller, L. Worcester, A.L. Hipp, K. Cameron; http://vplants.org/portal/checklists/checklist.php?cl=4892, and mirrored across the SEINet Portal Network). The identification guide is novel in providing paired identification guidelines, in which the non-native species are associated with native look-alikes; and in combining collections data with observational data to create distribution maps that reflect two user communities that often do not interact closely: the herbarium / museum community, and the aquatic invasives outreach / monitoring community (exemplified by EDDMapS, for example).
  • Teaching a workshop to K-12 science educators, providing them the training and resources needed to utilize museum collections in their classrooms. In June 2017, Arboretum staff taught a workshop entitled Branching Out: Collections in the Classroom. Five middle-school and high-school science teachers gained experience in plant collecting, using herbarium and specimen data to address questions in plant biodiversity, generating and analyzing morphometric data, and creating lesson plans that they implemented in their home schools. During the fall and spring semesters (2017-2018), Hipp attended 5 AP Biology classrooms, one special education classroom, and one 8th-grade classroom to assist with implementing the lesson plans the teachers had developed in the Branching out: Collections in the Classroom workshop. Two eighth-grade classrooms from the collaborating teachers also made visits to the Arboretum to gain additional experience in collections-based research. We also assisted with providing support for two teachers from the workshop to visit the Arboretum and Herbarium to continue to collect plants and make a plant collection for their classroom to directly teach students from.

In addition, the Arboretum exceeded its digitization goals by more than 10%: our goal was 18,000 specimens, and in the end we digitized a total of 21,425 specimen records digitized, 20,006 (93%) with images and 11% georeferenced. This represents a total of 1,016 species and, importantly, the majority of the contemporary records for the Chicago Region, as this collection was utilized for the landmark Flora of the Chicago Region: A Floristic and Ecological Synthesis, by G. Wilhelm and L. Rericha, which was published in the past year (2017; 1392 pp.; Indiana Academy of Science).

The project provided professional training to four early-career scientists; five K-12 teachers, who reached an estimated 250 students annually; and numerous volunteers who assisted in specimen digitization. Importantly, the project provides tools to help stop the spread of aquatic invasive species through earlier detection and greater public awareness to K-12 students as well as adults.
